q: What are the main symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: The main symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis) include intense pelvic pain, sudden strong urges to pee, needing to pee more often than usual, and pain in the lower tummy when the bladder is filling up.

q: Who is more likely to get BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: Although BPS (interstitial cystitis) can affect people of all ages, it is much more common in women than men, usually over the age of 30.

q: What are the possible causes of interstitial cystitis?
a: The exact cause of BPS (interstitial cystitis) is not clear, but possible causes include damage to the bladder lining, problems with pelvic floor muscles, and an inflammatory reaction caused by the immune system.

q: When should I see a GP for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: You should see a GP if you have pelvic pain that does not go away or if you notice a change in your usual peeing pattern that is affecting your daily life. If you have blood in your pee, ask for an urgent GP appointment.

q: What tests are done to diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: There is no single test to diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis), but you may have several tests to exclude other causes of your symptoms. These may include cystoscopy, urine tests, imaging scans, urodynamics, and vaginal swabs.

q: What treatments are available for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: There are several treatments for BPS (interstitial cystitis), including medications such as painkillers and medicines for nerve pain, bladder instillations, supportive therapies like physiotherapy and acupuncture, and surgery or other procedures in rare cases.

q: What can I do to help with BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: You can try reducing stress, staying hydrated, keeping a food diary to avoid trigger foods, and quitting smoking to help improve your symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis).

q: Where can I find more information and support for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: Bladder Health UK has information and forums on BPS (interstitial cystitis) and other bladder conditions.

q: Can BPS (interstitial cystitis) be diagnosed with a single test?
a: No, there is no single test to diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis). Multiple tests are usually performed to exclude other causes of your symptoms.

q: Are there any specific foods or drinks that should be avoided with BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: Certain foods and drinks like citrus fruits and alcohol may worsen symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis). However, it is recommended to ask for medical advice before making any dietary changes.

q: What are the main symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: The main symptoms of BPS (interstitial cystitis) include intense pelvic pain, sudden strong urges to pee, needing to pee more often than usual, pain in your lower tummy when your bladder is filling up, waking up several times during the night to pee, difficulty in peeing, urinary incontinence, and blood in the urine.

q: What tests may be done to diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: To diagnose BPS (interstitial cystitis), several tests may be done, including cystoscopy, urine tests, ultrasound, MRI scan or CT scan of the urinary tract and kidneys, urodynamics, and vaginal swabs.

q: What are the possible causes of interstitial cystitis?
a: The exact cause of BPS (interstitial cystitis) is not clear, but possible causes include damage to the bladder lining, problems with pelvic floor muscles, and inflammatory reactions caused by the immune system. It may also be associated with chronic conditions such as fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, and irritable bowel syndrome.

q: What treatments are available for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: There are several treatments for BPS (interstitial cystitis), including medication such as painkillers, nerve pain medication, and bladder relaxants. Bladder instillations, supportive therapies like physiotherapy and acupuncture, as well as surgery and procedures, can also be options to manage the condition.

q: When should I see a GP for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: You should see a GP if you have pelvic pain that does not go away, notice a change in your usual peeing pattern, or if blood is present in your urine. An urgent GP appointment is necessary if you have blood in your pee.

q: Who is more likely to get BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: While BPS (interstitial cystitis) can affect people of all ages, it is more common in women, usually over the age of 30. The symptoms may come and go over time and can be influenced by factors like the menstrual cycle, certain foods, or drinks.

q: What are some things I can do to help manage BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: To help manage BPS (interstitial cystitis), you can try reducing stress, staying hydrated, keeping a food diary to avoid trigger foods, and quitting smoking, as it can irritate the bladder. It is always advisable to seek medical advice before making any changes.

q: When should I ask a GP for a referral to a hospital specialist?
a: If the treatments from your GP are not effective and your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be appropriate to ask for a referral to a urologist specializing in female urology or a urogynaecologist. Men may be referred to a urologist.

q: What are some supportive therapies and treatments for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: Some supportive therapies and treatments for BPS (interstitial cystitis) include physiotherapy, acupuncture, talking therapies and counseling, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), and pain management. These therapies can help alleviate symptoms and improve your quality of life.

q: Are there any surgeries or procedures for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: In some cases, surgeries or procedures may be recommended for BPS (interstitial cystitis). These can include cauterization to seal ulcers, bladder distension to aid diagnosis, botulinum toxin injections to reduce symptoms, neuromodulation to stimulate nerves, and, in very rare cases, bladder removal.

q: Where can I find more information and support for BPS (interstitial cystitis)?
a: Bladder Health UK provides information and forums on BPS (interstitial cystitis), as well as other bladder conditions. They can be a valuable resource for additional information and support.
